Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics of RNA dependent RNA polymerases

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms by which a virus, vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) replicates. VSV has a similar RNA genome to other potent human and animal pathogens such as Ebola and measles. When VSV enters a host cell it synthesizes an enzyme, RNA dependent RNA Polymerases (RdRPs) that copies the viral RNA genome. This project will examine the mechanism by which RdRPs read and copy the viral genome template in infected cells, which is critical for the replication of viruses. The results from this study will improve scientific understanding of how RdRPs work and identify potential target mechanisms for inhibition of viral infections. This study will train students who are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, by engaging them within teams doing research at the University of Utah and University of Massachusetts Medical School at Worcester. The proposed activities will also support development of Biophysics courses that will benefit undergraduate interdisciplinary education, and encourage participation of K-12 students in science by communicating aspects of the scientific results through creation of a "virus dance" project.

This project will use single molecule live cell imaging to visualize transcription events from single VSV genome templates in infected cells and utilize fluorescence correlation spectroscopy to measure the concentration of free RdRPs during transcription in vivo. When stretched, the genome template of VSV is more than 4 microns in size and RdRPs can only initiate transcription on its 3' end. While 50 RdRPs are tightly bound to this template, how they initiate and sustain transcription is not clear. The live cell imaging experiments will determine the number of active RdRPs per genome and their cooperativity. Measurements of the concentration of free RdRPs not bound to the genome will verify if a dissociation and 3' binding mechanism can support viral transcription in vivo. This project will also use reconstituted templates in vitro to visualize the mechanism by which RdRPs redistribute on the genome template. We have observed single RdRP sliding on purified genome templates in vitro. In this project we will further characterize the sliding mechanism of RdRPs on genome templates. By measuring the dynamics of RdRPs in vivo as well as in vitro this project will determine the mechanism of transcription by RdRPs during VSV RNA virus infection.

The project was funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: Many Enveloped RNA viruses, package special enzymes which are crucial for their infectivity. VSV which is a prototype single strand negative sense RNA virus packages the RNA dependent RNA polymerases (RdRP) to transcribe and replicate its genomic RNA. Without the genomic processing power of RdRPs the viral infection will cease to proceed after viral entry to new hosts. Its not just the negative strand RNA viruses which package viral enzymes. Retroviruses including HIV, package reverse transcriptase, integrase and protease enzymes to aid the virus both re-organize structurally during viral maturation as well as convert RNA genomes to DNA for incorporation into hosts. How are these viral enzymes packaged and how do they work on their substrates is a fundamental question in viral replication and genome processing. Viruses are however extremely small, not visible even with the most powerful light microscopes due to the limits of diffraction, they had escaped characterization up to the invention of electron microscopes at the early 20th century. The low copy number of viral enzymes packaged in each individual viral particle as well as heterogeneity of viral particles makes studying these viral enzymes a special challenge.

Accomplishments: Fluorescence microscopy offers specificity in terms of linking enzymes of interest with fluorescent proteins which can then be localized using light microscopy. In order to make viral enzymes visible in a light microscope therefore the enzymes need to be fused to fluorescent proteins in a manner that maintains their functionality. During the period of our award, we have tagged the M, P and L proteins of the VSV with various fluorescent proteins and screened for functionality of these viral enzymes. We have identified specific fusion and tagging strategies which allow these viral enzymes to remain functional in their genomic processing. Tagging the viral enzymes however by itself is not sufficient for direct observation of their function, since most of the time, these enzymes work and or are packaged in complexes which include anywhere from 1-50 enzymes. The next challenge has been to identify individual enzymes within these complexes with sufficient resolution. In order to solve this problem, we developed an application of interferometric PALM (iPALM) microscopy to study viral packaging in individual viral particles or viral genomes. The first step in this development was identification of a suitable photo switchable fluorescent protein which can be stochastically turned on and photo bleached during iPALM measurements, we identified the Dendra fluorescent protein as the best choice for tagging viral enzymes for their localization. We then developed a series of VSV P, and L enzymes tagged with the Dendra protein. During this award, an iPALM microscope was made functional at the University of Utah which has a voxel resolution of 10 nm and allows localization of viral enzymes within the confines of viral particles with sizes ranging from 100-200 nm. To test this microscope, we recreated a known structural landmark namely HIV Gag immature lattice. Using the combination of the iPALM technology developed in our lab and fusion of Dendra molecules within the confines of HIV, we were able to visualize the cavity as well as lattice defects previously only visible through electron cryo-tomography measurements.

The arrival of COVID-19 was a sudden reminder of the deadly nature of RNA enveloped viruses, in this case SARS-CoV-2. As an NSF funded lab focused on enveloped RNA viruses, we were capable to respond rapidly. In the first stage of our response, we made our expertise in harvesting viral particles available in collaboration which allowed investigations into the sensitivity of SARS-CoV-2 virions to various environmental conditions. SARS-CoV-2 contains many key structural proteins including M, S and E proteins. While a lot of attention has been focused on SARS-CoV-2 S proteins which form the basis of all current vaccines, there is a lot less known about M and E proteins. Utilizing the technologies developed in this award, we have identified a method to tag the SARS-CoV-2 M protein with the Dendra fluorescent protein. Furthermore, using the iPALM technology developed in this award, we have been able to count and localize the M proteins within individual SARS-CoV-2 viral particles.    

This award has supported three undergraduate students which successfully transitioned to PhD granting graduate programs as well as two graduate students, one of which successfully defended her PhD in 2020 and one who will defend her PhD in 2021.
